messages.content: Why does the flag of the Isle of Mann have those weird legs?

The flag of the Isle of Man, also known as the "Three Legs of Man," features three legs rather than the traditional two legs on a flag because the island is situated between the British Isles and the European continent. The legs are meant to symbolize the island's strategic location at the crossroads of the Irish Sea and the North Atlantic, as well as its history as a trading hub and a gateway between the British Isles and the rest of Europe. The flag was first used in the 13th century and has been the official flag of the Isle of Man since the 19th century.
Has the symbol been used elsewhere?

The symbol of the three legs on the flag of the Isle of Man has not been used elsewhere as far as I am aware. However, the concept of a triskelion, which is a symbol consisting of three interconnected legs or arms, has been used in various cultures throughout history. For example, the triskelion is a common symbol in Celtic art, and it has been found in the art and mythology of other cultures around the world, such as in Greek and Slavic traditions. The triskelion has also been used as a symbol of unity, strength, and stability, and it has been incorporated into various logos and designs.
